commentBody:
Lapsus linguae.

Isn't that a blue gemstone?

Hi all, it's my day to promote The Griddies - with an easy to use ballot to vote on the PUZZLE OF THE YEAR for 2024. https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059 You'll see 4 categories: M-W Thu Fri-Sat Sun Vote for as many as FIVE in each category. First round voting ends midnight Jan. 24, the top ones in each category will be on the second round ballot. https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059
Clever and enjoyable, but pretty easy for a Wednesday.

This was a lot of fun! Cluing was clever, without much reliance on trivia, and once I figured out the trick it all fell into place in a very satisfying way.

Congrats to Landon for the debut!
Fun, interesting and unique!

Very smooth puzzle with a theme that actually helped me a bit.  My only hiccup was having nudge instead of BUDGE and not seeing that OKAYnE made no sense until I got the dread almost finished keep trying message.

A charming, marvelous debut. Very clever interplay of the double letters among the theme clues. I always enjoy reading the constructor notes, particularly when they convey the obvious joy of that first time in print. I'll look forward to the next puzzle from Mr. Horton.
The Brooklyn Dodgers' Peewee Reese  stood 5'10" tall ‚Äî average height. He earned his  nickname playing marbles as a boy (small marbles are called "peewees").
That was a really nice solve

Nice Wednesday puzzle.

The theme was clever and well-executed, and the fill was solid.

8.5/10.

Managed to snarf this one down very quickly!

An excellent, breezy Wednesday. Thanks, Landon Horton!
Really enjoyed the ‚Äúno pun‚Äù intended when it was clearly and ever so intended.  Well done.

The puzzle was cute, but my two favorite laughs tonight are:

‚ÄúHot air bassoon‚Äù from Landon
‚ÄúSpoonerism by accident‚Äù from Sam

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Mr. Horton! 

I found it more challenging than the typical Wednesday puzzle, especially in the NW corner. It wasn't until I switched LOon for LOCO that I could see BREAK THE ICE (which should've been obvious much sooner).

Hope we'll see you back again!
Great debut, Landon! Very clever and fun. Glad you stuck with it (or should I say KEPT TO?). Looking forward to seeing what you do next.

A tiptop Wednesday, that was interesting and evocative and just plain fun, from Mama Bear to Jay Gatsby to that unlikely pair of poets and those unexpected MIXED DOUBLES.  Of course it was an impressive debut, but more than that, the whole puzzle was fresh and relied on only a tiny few "oleos." 

Fittingly, this one was bottoms up for me‚Äîa slow start, but soon enough the fills were flowing from clues that were both witty and confident. I knew that I was in good hands and started to really enjoy myself. 

Thank you, Landon Horton. and for our sake, may the force continue to be with you.

Congratulations on your debut, Landon.  I enjoyed the theme, and it was useful in getting some answers that I may have not have gotten otherwise.

Time was 28% less than average.

On the billboard, one of the eyes of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg had developed a stye, but they did not budge from staring down at us as we rumbled through the Valley of Ashes on the way to the City. There, in the hot hotel room, Tom Buchanan would break the ice as he mixed doubles of gin with shots of sambuca, and then yelled at the bellhop, a poet from Iberia, to wheel the drinking buggy away. "And get us each a rare rib-eye, you lazy Arab!" he shouted, "None of that pub grub!"

Dressed to the nines in Armani, he turned to Daisy and asked, "What do you see in this playboy buddy of yours, anyway?" and watched her skin redden, first her nape and then her ear. She turned to me, silently mouthing "Help me!" I put my hand in my pocket and felt the cool steel of one of the razors I keep to use in just such a situation as this. I turned to Tom and beamed from ear to ear, as if I was the avatar of a loco god, said a prayer to Mama and ---

I can't do it. I just can't bring myself to do in Tom Buchanan in this awful, blasphemous version of Gatsby. Off to see the Dylan movie: I hear that Chalamet kid can really do Bob, and that Edward Norton channeling Pete Seeger is simply uncanny it's so true. Don't forget to vote (for puzzle of the year, that is, otherwise, it's all over, Baby Blue).

Congratulations on your debut, Mr. Horton, and a fine one it is.

A round of applause to you for persisting through 19 rejections just to bring us some glorious entertainment.
And another round of applause for this very worthy and delightful puzzle.

Thank you!

There is a theory that CONEY ISLAND got its name from the Dutch word for rabbit, due to a purported large population of wild rabbits on the island. Nice crossing with BUNNY. 

Fun theme! Congratulations on your debut, Landon.

This was fun. I can imagine the elation upon receipt of the acceptance letter!  

I liked the theme. Maybe some constructor could get their head around this collection of words with common endings and come up with a puzzle:

Patroon
Dragoon
Lagoon
Maroon
Festoon
Cartoon
Quadroon
Spittoon

‚ÄúNO PUN‚Äù just sounds like a (definitely intended) dare for our resident punster Mike‚Ä¶

Maybe it‚Äôs just a wavelength thing, but I found this puzzle surprisingly easy. I also thought it was clever and fun‚Äî just what I needed at the end of a long day!

Speaking of which, I think a DRINKING BUGGY sounds like a fine idea. Anyone care to join me? We can BREAK THE ICE into some glasses and pour the SAMBUCA, or enjoy some DOUBLE shots (mixed or otherwise). Later on, maybe even TOKE a little LOCO weed. I told you, it‚Äôs been a long day.
12 seconds off my Wednesday best and faster than either Monday or Tuesday
Absolutely tickled by this puzzle, and earned my best time for a Wednesday! Congrats on the debut, Landon!
A pleasure to solve!

Fun theme and some great clues with EAR, HELPME, BOOS, MAMA, HARDG and EWE. I liked the clue for PEEWEE but also found myself wishing it was Herman-related. KGB was also a missed opportunity IMO and could have been a great historical clue instead of another TV reference. Like ‚ÄúKomitet Gosudarstvenoy Bezopasnosti, if you were Russian through it?‚Äù PUN intended!

TIL the word spoonerism. This phenomenon is common in my household, esp. when we don‚Äôt get a lot of sleep, resulting in many great laughs over the dinner table. My kids still tease me about how ‚ÄúSnip snaped‚Äù  (instead of Snape snipped) during one of our many hours of Harry Potter read alouds in the last few years.

So far this week I've been completing puzzles faster every day - filling today's grid took 2 minutes less than yesterday's and 3 minutes less than Monday's. Last week my solve times were all over the place, too. Either I'm special or the editing in recent weeks has been a bit... Eccentric?
Thoroughly enjoyed this one. Thank you.

Somehow I find I solve more downs than across, so I typically start with down. I also always enjoy when the clue requires someone to think about it phonetically vs. semantically and it always makes me smile when I‚Äôm corrected!

This being said for 8D I was reluctant to put A BALL simply because I felt like two words, specifically using the article ‚Äúa‚Äù is rare, but then I saw KEPT TO and NO PUN so put it in. Figured it out once I started the crosses and it was delightful  being wrong, gave me a good chuckle.

47A was a breeze.

I wish there was a way to *save* my favorite puzzles on the app!

Was this Wednesday? It was so frunchy (did we make that portmanteau a thing?)! Great job, Landon.

I had to chuckle at 14D because on the group chat my kids had a big laugh at how I hold GRUDGES for them that they have long forgotten. 

Me: ‚ÄúRemember when Emilie grabbed your arm in fourth grade and pulled you down the hallway?‚Äù  Daughter: ‚ÄúUm, no‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that the guy who tried to embarrass you in front of the soldiers in your squad?‚Äù
Son: ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù
Me: ‚ÄúIn November of 2023, right before your Thanksgiving leave.‚Äù 

Heaven HELPME to bite my tongue when I see those ‚Äúoffenders‚Äù üòÇ Yeah, I‚Äôm a LOCO (but actually harmless) MAMA bear üêª 

Have a great day, everyone!
That was a fun puzzle. Good job, Landon! Keep'em coming.

Bizarrely I always thought SAMBUCA was a Greek drink, because a flaming one was always offered at the end of the meal in a favourite Greek restaurant back in the 80‚Äôs (the place was in Leeds, not Greece. Sadly I couldn‚Äôt afford holidays in my impoverished youth). Huh. TIL.

Good puzzle, crunchy but fun. I love the MIXED DOUBLES theme; not difficult but a great ‚ÄòOh, yeah‚Äô moment when the spoonerisms are revealed.

Clever crossword. 
For me, some unknowns, like PTO - bankable vacation, both not known to me, and the hot dog eating, the names of famous people and Final Four. 
I saw Star Wars in 1977 and what who said to whom is long gone. 
I thought UAE must be a University!

Typical long Wednesday workout for me, but a really enjoyable puzzle. Just a lot of fun working out each of the theme answers. Glad to see another new constructor and looking forward to more from Mr. Horton. 

And... one answer search today was inspired by our constructor's name. Dawned on me that HORTONHEARSAWHO is 15 letters and that led me to discover that there are at least three other Dr. Seuss books with 15 letter titles, and some of those appeared together in more than a couple of puzzles. The others being: 

GREENEGGSANDHAM
YERTLETHETURTLE
and
IFIRANTHECIRCUS

Just seems like an odd coincidence. Might put another puzzle find in a reply. 

...

*Crossword Revolution Day 1: CONEY ISLAND ‚ÄúConey Island Baby‚Äù by Lou Reed. Glory of love The glory of love The glory of love, might see you through Yeah, but now, now Glory of love The glory of love The glory of love might see you through Glory of love, uh, huh-huh The glory of love Glory of love, glory of love Glory of love, now, glory of love, now Glory of love, now, now, now, glory of love Glory of love, give it to me now, glory of love to see you through, huh. https://youtube.com/watch?v=t0dsDJFJ1jk * A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production. All rights reserved.

Skin-of-the-teeth completion for me without lookups. SO many complete unknowns. Hung for a long time until I got the X in O_IDE, which started an avalanche of solves, culminating in a right-on-third-attempt guess for the cross between the magic 8 ball (whatever that is) and the Taiwanese president.

(Slightly surprised, on a quick scroll through, that the End Of Civilization is not being predicted by the Usage Police now that the NYT has equated "deny" and "refute".)

Just chiming in with the rest in congratulating Landon for constructing a very fun Wednesday puzzle. 
Tight clueing, clever gimmick, and just an overall enjoyable solve.
Thank you, Landon!
Landon, congratulations, your dogged perseverance is commendable! Thanks for taking the long and winding road and arriving at this wonderful Wednesday wordplay.

Two great moments, one actual and one I imagine.

The actual.  After uncovering the theme answers, I tried to guess the revealer after leaving it blank and not reading its clue.  Nothing came.  So, I tried the next step ‚Äì revealing its first word (MIXED), and in a mighty flash, saw DOUBLES.  Oh man, the kick of solve-ation mixed with the realization at how perfect the reveal was, well, that was a moment.  A high.

The imagined.  There‚Äôs Landon trying to clue HORSE AND BUNNY without sounding mundane.  I mean, you try coming up with one!  And then [Mare/hare pair?] hit him.  I‚Äôm guessing that was a ‚ÄúThank you, heavens‚Äù moment for him.

Lovely serendipities today:
‚Ä¢	A short-U fest: BUDDY/BUNNY/BUGGY plus BUDGE, GRUDGES, RUSTS, NOPUN, DRUB, and twice in PUBGRUB.
‚Ä¢	GALLOP and HORSE kissing corners.
‚Ä¢	The homophone of ‚Äúbooze‚Äù crossing an alcoholic beverage (SAMBUCA).
‚Ä¢	Three three-letter e-sandwich palindromes (ELE, EWE, and the EYE of RIBEYE).

Landon, I‚Äôm inspired by your persistence in continuing to submit puzzles to the Times after 19 rejections, and I‚Äôm thrilled by the happy ending.  Thank you for a most impressive theme and for that pummeled-by-happiness moment!

Landon, congratulations on a sparkling debut!

Debut-iful!

Happy Wednesday all!

üê™

In Mr. Carson's absence, here's the Strands.  I got a Well Done! after finishing. SRSLY?

Strands #325
‚ÄúPixar this‚Äù
üí°üîµüí°üîµ
üí°üîµüí°üîµ
üí°üîµüü°üîµ

No spoilers until after the fold, please.

Very nice puzzle, much enjoyed! Thanks and congratulations to Landon Horton!
Super theme, too. Often you can just ignore the theme and notice it after finishing, but today's grabbed my attention and took a good while to reveal itself. Exactly as it should be.
üëè
What I like about this puzzle is the DD, NN, and GG. A nice touch.

And interesting "permutation" theme here. Not sure I've seen this before. The start of each of the three thematic entries correctly pairs with the end of the next thematic entry, in a cyclic pattern: 1 --> 2, 2 --> 3, 3 --> 1. Or just (123) in cycle notation.

MIXEDDOUBLES seems a good revealer for this theme.

TYCO/TSAI meeting at the T worried me, though I vaguely recalled the company name and TSAI made sense as a Taiwanese family name.

Got HARDG immediately today, avoiding yesterday's MELC debacle.

Congrats on the debut!

I just love seeing a debut puzzle! Congratulations, Landon. 
I get carsick, so maybe a DRINKINGBUGGY would work better for me than a party bus, as long as they didn't go at a GALLOP. 
Speaking of which, I had "canter" in there first. Not for long, thank goodness.
Have a good Wednesday!

An excellent theme for an excellent debut!

I wanted 30D to be cheese curds. My recommendation: a Surly Furious IPA and cheese curds at the Nook in Saint Paul. You can get a Juicy Lucy there, but their patty melt is my favorite.
Easy peasy puzzle.  Maybe all the griping of late is bearing fruit?

Thanks, Mr. Horton, for your perseverance! Enjoyed the result. 

I‚Äôve always thought I might give constructing a try‚Ä¶ but never mind the perseverance, I‚Äôm not sure I have the years left to get through 19 tries!

Welcome, Landon!  
However....I really wanted HORSE AND BUGSY at 31A.  
And this puzzle seemed to be swarming with B's; please note that some of us are allergic.

The OBOE is a delightful (and important) instrument, but none of us Band members found it especially "thin," nor considered it a quality of note.  Flutes, drumsticks, the conductor's baton--now, those are thin. Ish.  

Please get busy on our next treat!

Wow! Huge respect for sticking to constructing. Having the perseverance pay off with a smooth puzzle like this that gets published is a win, but another real accomplishment is finding something as challenging as crossword construction that you enjoy.
Wow! So very clever. I got 20A, 31A, and 38A correctly, and even with the giveaway of 51A it took me a few minutes to see the DD,  NN, and GG swaps. Lots‚Äôa fun.
Be prepared to get nerd slammed for 8 across!

The comments today feel more playful than usual, perhaps inspired by the nature of the puzzle and Sam‚Äôs column.

I have a high regard for constructors of all stripes, but especially one that perseveres through 19 rejections to be published in the NYT. Congratulations, Landon! It‚Äôs clear from the column and comments that this puzzle was something special.

Thank you, Landon and Sam, this morning, for sliding me down that polyunsaturated rabbit-hole of bad chemistry and bad gastronomy, hard and soft g's, which is Butterine, aka OI√©omargarine, aka Margarine, aka Oleo. Too much even to summarize--at one point, between OED, M-W, and Wikipedia, I had six tabs open. One take-away--the (British) Parliamentary Margarine Act of 1887, with a legal mandate of the term "margarine,"  over "oleo(margarine)" or "butterine". Not to be confused with the (American) Congressional Margarine Act of 1886, which tried (unsuccessfully) to ban its production and sale entirely. Neither, however, addressed the "g" controversy.. Also, the OED lists a verb form, "(to) margarine," which is what Frank's Diner does to my toast, too liberally for my taste, unless I tell them not to. Frank's isn't far, but today it's too cold to walk--maybe I'll just take a taxicab instead.
Breezed through it.  No longer feel like a beginner.

Quick and fun ‚Äì and for once I figured out the trick without brain pain :-D. 

I'm amazed the columnist had never heard of DRUB, as DRUBBING is a common sports term, for example: The Montr√©al Canadiens took a DRUBBING from the Toronto Maple Leafs the other night, as they blew a 3-0 lead at the end of the first period, and lost 7-3.

(Apologies to the Habs fans LOL LOL)
Boy, the rabbit holes you end up going down some days! TIL that the # sign has a name: octothorpe. Who knew!?

I can sure relate to everything Landon said. Applause for hanging in there, and Well Done!
For some reason I always thought having a word show up in the grid and a clue was not allowed (horse). Good to know...
Excellent debut, Landon...hit all the right mid-week marks! Bravo.
TIL grawlix. Though if #!@*&% shows up in a clue on Saturday, I‚Äôll probably just curse myself for not being able to remember it.

It‚Äôs pretty cold out there today. I‚Äôll be dressing to the -25s
with a few mixed double-knits.

What do you call that tall, lazy guy on your baseball team?
Peewee hustle.
(Did I just say that? For real?)

One of these days, the answer will be BROMO-Seltzer, and only solvers from Baltimore will get it. (They stopped making it in 1975, when bromides were determined to be toxic.) You can see the Bromo-Seltzer Tower from Oriole Park, with the brand name emblazoned on its clock faces.
It's irritating when you offer FIVE correct answers (including hole) to a Connections category. What fun is that? It's just chance whether or not you correctly fill the category.
Just wanted to add my appreciation and congratulations! This was a great puzzle and a great debut!
Loved it

No hints or lookups today felt like a win. The NW corner gave me fits! KEEPTO doesn't sit well as a thing anyone actually says in my experience. I went through every possible variation of KEEP___ before landing on that because I finally figured out OPTS and TOKES independently. Probably just me but those three clues (in combo with 20A being extremely non-obvious) weren't doing anything for me today. While I certainly did not find this puzzle breezy, as some others have suggested, I am learning to just stick with the trouble spots, start a section over, and walk away periodically. Eventually it clears up as it did today. And the feeling of triumph is all the better when it follows a prolonged struggle.

Am I missing something? Isn‚Äôt having an answer in a clue a big no-no?
clue 2D: Racehorse‚Äôs gait
clue 38A: Horse-drawn party vehicle?
31A: HORSEANDBUNNY.

I was so sure this wasn‚Äôt allowed I refused to enter HO until the very end. I‚Äôm genuinely shocked this was allowed and that it hasn‚Äôt been commented on yet (that I see).

A very fun puzzle. Just shocked by the clueing.

Fun and cute puzzle today.  Congrats Landon on your debut!  Stay warm everyone!  Supposed to hit 20 today!  Better than my sis in MN, where it was 17 below yesterday.

I've decided to change up my game playing going forward.  No more Connections!

Congratulations on a delightful debut, Landon Horton. This was such fun, and I‚Äôm looking forward to your next puzzle. And, as always, your column was endearing and entertaining, Sam. We really need the joy of daily puzzles right now. ü´£
Enjoyed this one.  Figuring out the theme not only took some brainpower, but once figured out it also helped solve the tricky upper-middle section.

(Posted earlier, but it has disappeared) Someone should tell Wyna and Sam that "restaurateur" is misspelled in the 3 Down clue in today's Mini Crossword (actually, I hope they know by now). See https://ciachef.edu/blog/what-happened-to-the-n-in-restaurateur

I twice had answers I was confident were correct.    Much wasted time before I finally figured out:  BRINGtheIce was BreakTheIce.    And NOTas intended was NoPun intended.     Just one of those days for me... came in 4 minutes slower than average.

I recently discovered that my NYT subscription includes the Crossword Puzzle.  I used to do it in the paper with pen every day - and then stopped, took 20 years off, and am back.  I'm working backwards, too, going through the archives.

I must say, it's amazing how many words repeat and repeat and repeat.  "EGOT" has been in at least 10 puzzles over the past four months.  Kelly Ripa was a popular clue 25 years ago.

On the other hand, one would have never seen "Tokes" in 1997.
That was one for my hairy humerus.

Wisconsin, former home and Dairy State, banned the sale of OLEOmargarine for some time. Wisconsin was also the home of Duncan yo-yos. 

Oh yeah the puzzle, smooth sailing. A pleasant Wednesday,

Thank you Landon
My favorite Spoonerism of all time comes to us courtesy of my ex-wife, when we were shopping for hardwood flooring at...wait for it...Liquid Lumberdators.

Great puzzle!
As a new crossworder, I really enjoyed this.  It was hard (I'm a math guy and a bad speller) but had enough easier crosses that allowed me to guess the harder clues.
The theme was really cool and once I figured it out, it helped me finish the puzzle.   I would have never figured out the "Develops iron 49-Down" without the 'X' from mixed doubles - brilliant clue!!!
I hope the Times accepts more of your puzzles!
TYCO and TSAI crossed together was not nice. Not to mention SAMBUCA, which I wanted to spell with a K.
Very fun puzzle today! Thanks, Landon!

Breezy and fun Wednesday puzzle. Loved the theme and am wondering who will run with the idea of a DRINKINGBUGGY. Honestly sounds like more fun than those cycle carts. Some hot toddies and mulled wine during a horse-drawn carriage ride? Count me in!

Yesterday, I was proud to announce to the world that, after 8.5 months of NYT crosswording, I finally achieved a milestone and completed a puzzle without any lookups. (In my defence, I don't even go here - here being America. And yes, I just quoted Mean Girls!)

Oh. Em. Gee. (Note: this isn't a HARDG.) Now slap my face and call me a Valley Girl, I've just gone and done it again. Two days in a row without any lookups. Is it a full moon? A blue moon? That other moon variant where it looks super huge... I forget what's it's called?!! ü§î

I BEAMED. I stared in AWE. I downed a couple of shots of SAMBUCA to celebrate. I'll need a couple of ALKA-Seltzers in the morning but who cares, I'm gonna go LOCO tonight.

OKBYE.
Thanks for the terrific theme, which was also very well clued. It was a great pleasure after a long day.

Nice puzzle. I love it when I can ignore the "theme" and just solve it. The downs gave me the jokey-jokes. I still don't even know what the "theme" is and I'm fine with that. A new best time for a Wednesday.
Really loved this crossword. Challenging enough but not *so* much that I was stuck. Hoping to see more like these!
thanks, landon horton. i LOVED solving this puzzle! the buddy/bunny/buggy switcheroo is SO clever. i hope we get to see many more of your creations.
Rik Smits? Haven't thought about him in ages!
Am I LOCO or was this really easy for a Wednesday?

Reading right down the middle ---
SAMBUCA GRUDGES
Sounds like the title of a Broadway hit.



OKAY, BYE.
Monday took more than double my average Monday time, yet today took less than half my average Wednesday time and 20 minutes faster than Monday. Go figure.

Oh my, this was a lovely, lovely, and sparkly puzzle!  Many smiles in this one üòä. 

Thank you Landon, for your hard work and persistence. We hope to see more from you!
Loved this.   Clever, funny, entertaining.   And no insidious naticks.   Great debut, Mr. Horton.   Keep 'em coming!

@Steve L 

Good one, Steve!

@Steve L 
Yes, of course you‚Äôre right. Just as lapsus linguae e calami is squid ink pasta. :)
Nice job POY Committee.

@Eric Hougland -- Good question (or one I hadn't thought of anyway). I would suggest using the time in Kiribati, Micronesia, since that time zone is the last on earth to reach midnight on the 24th: "UTC+14:00." -- don't know how many votes we're going to get from Oceania, hoping for a lot -- but in any case I'll take it up with the Committee! :-)
@Wendy Laubach Surprisingly easy for a Wednesday. I didn't really get stuck on anything today, usually at least a few words stump me temporarily.

@Wendy Laubach 
I think the Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles got switched.  I needed no cheats for the "Wednesday", but I did for the "Tuesday".  Very fun, just the same.

@Wendy Laubach 

Hmm. I found it a bit more challenging than most Wednesdays, probably because BREAK THE ICE took me much longer to get than in should have.
@Striker You made me snort-laugh at snarf ü§£
@Eric Hougland I had Loon also.

@john ezra 

This reminded me of a spoonerism I once blurted out in a college class discussion about the author‚ÄîF. Skit Fotchgerald.  Thought I'd never hear the end of it.

@Puzzlemucker 

Thanks Muckie! (I think Newbie used to call you that). I miss Newbie too. Such a sweet and funny person.

@Puzzlemucker 

Newbie came to mind for me when I was solving this puzzle! It was very late last night and I had to review the grid just now to see where that may have been. I guess it was TOKES, and that I heard it in his voice... Newbie if you're out there, we miss your voice!

@Anita 

That was the answer/question on the most recent episode of Jeopardy, category FROM THE DUTCH

@William Schrader 

these were complaining that they were left out:

Macaroon 
Balloon

I'm sure there are a lot more... but you get my point. I'll let the constructors do the rest...

@Rachel 

But... these weren't spoonerisms?


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Rachel we are reading the HP books with my 11 year old.  I recently referred to a certain class as Defense Against the Ark Darts. He thought it was hilarious and reminds me at least a few times a week.  

I also recently mixed up Harry and Sirius and created a new character named Harius.
@Steve Defense Against the Ark Darts: You never know when Noah's going to shoot.

@Andrzej 

Opposite for me; today +40 seconds over yesterday, Tuesday 3+ minutes over Monday

@Andrzej for me, yesterday and today were within a second of each other, and a minute longer than Monday. My averages are  3 Monday-Tuesday and  5 Tuesday-Wednesday. So yeah, a bit odd so far this week.

@AT 

Your wish is a brilliant idea! My memory is beyond horrible, but I would like to vote for my favorite puzzles in the poll linked below by @john ezra. However, I just don't remember which puzzles I liked most, and I can't be bothered to check them one by one using the dates provided in the poll. Being able to have a favorites list would be awsome!
@AT I agree with you. This puzzle is definitely one for a favorites of 2025 list. Great idea. Now, if I can just remember that I started the list!

@Andrzej 

Well, the URLs are straightforward and bookmarkable for each puzzle.... if you remember to do it... and if you have bookmark/favorite organizing skills beyond my own enormous-endless-pile approach.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

I solve in the app, not in my browser. And my bookmarks are a horrible mess ü§™
@Helen Wright Ahh, a kindred spirit. I paid attention then and I pay attention now.  They say remembering every detail of those incidents is my superpower!

@Pani Korunova and Helen

Oh, the wrath of a mamma bear‚Äôs memory!

I promised to let them fight their own battles, but that didn‚Äôt mean I couldn‚Äôt stare down the kid that wouldn‚Äôt let my boy sit next to him on the bus unless he paid him.

I was volunteering in the classroom and had 
this kid at a table with no witnesses.

‚ÄúSo, when he gets on the bus, and he gets to your seat‚Ä¶what is it that you do? Because, you know I‚Äôm *watching* you from my front door‚Ä¶ So, tell me‚Ä¶what *is* it that you *do*?‚Äù

First grade. I broke the spirit of a 6 year-old.
But he never charged him again.

And I‚Äôll get over it. 
It‚Äôs only been 22 years. 
I‚Äôm thinking‚Ä¶30?‚Ä¶40?

@CCNY 
You go girl.

@Helen Wright 

It was SAMBUCA in my youth as well; somehow I never learned of ouzo until I was an adult! Blame it perhaps on not having visited Greece either. I did have a Eurail pass while on holiday during my study abroad year of college -- but Greece was too difficult to reach in the time allotted. The pass prohibited travel in eastern bloc countries, so the only passage was via the "slow boat" from Brindisi, Italy. We vacationed in Italy instead! Maybe I even had Sambuca then? @G omg this brings back memories. I spent a great  two months in 1981 traipsing around Europe on a second-class Eurail pass. @Jane Wheelaghan 

I know the Star Wars line very well - but for years I only knew it in... German :D

Hilf mir, Obi wan Kenobi! Ihr seid meine letzte Hoffnung!

I first watched Star Wars on VHS - a bootleg copy purchased on the black market for 8 year old me by my mom in the late 80s. It was dubbed in German, with a another guy talking over all the lines in Polish.

There was no legal market for VHS tapes back then, so all the tapes were bootlegs, usually copied from originals acquired in Germany and smuggled across the border. The practice was not illegal per se, as Poland introduced Wester-style copyright laws only in 1994, 5 years after the fall of "communism".

The copying underground was well organized - few people spoke German, so the bootleggers hired translators, and then a voice actor to recite the lines, which were added to the sound mix over the original dialog.

BTW, in Poland on modern TV, foreign films are neither subtitled nor dubbed - much like in the bootleg VHS days, a single voice actor recites lines in Polish with the original dialog still audible in the background. It is very weird, and one of the many reasons (the other being commercial breaks) I never watch traditional TV. Dubbing is reserved for childrens' movies (on TV and in cinemas), and subtitles for cinematic releases. On streaming apps there is usually the choice between subtitles and the traditional Polish solution of one person reading all the lines.

@ging 

I understood "bankable" in financial (salary) terms. 

Like you, my PTO never rolled over more than a few months past when it was expected to be used. (My partner, in the public sector, has some that never expires!)

However, were you to leave the company, they are *required* to pay you for any unused PTO. Thus, bankable! Part of your compensation in your contract. (Whereas "personal days" are typically "use it or lose it" time off.)

Of course, PTO can mean more than just vacation days. I was working at a place many (many !) years ago when the practice first came into use. Previously we had X vacation days (determined by your contract) plus 10 measly sick days in a year. They then combined these, effectively reducing sick leave even more -- because who's going to take a sick day when vacation beckons? Human nature lol.

@Jane Wheelaghan The hot dog eating is a famous event held annually on Independence Day: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathan%27s_Hot_Dog_Eating_Contest And for more on Coney Island's cultural resonance, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island Although TIL, in looking for these links to share, that there is an actual* island in Ireland of the same name! *The Coney Island here in Brooklyn is actually part of a peninsula.

@G I meant to add that there is a style of hot dog known as a "coney" -- and a type of restaurant known as "Coney Island" -- that perhaps ironically do not exist in NYC but instead primarily in the midwest! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island_hot_dog https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island_%28restaurant%29

@G CONEY ISLAND started out as an island, but a stretch of the water separating it from mainland Brooklyn was landfilled over several decades: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island_Creek#/media/File:1879_Coney_Island.jpg Another fun fact: CONEY originally rhymed with honey and money. That's one reason the animal is now known as a rabbit. But since it was in the King James Bible, clergy charged with pronouncing it aloud in church switched the pronunciation to rhyme with phoney and baloney. If you don't get why this was a problem, pronounce honey and money and then similarly pronounce CONEY.
@G Coney Island was a typical barrier island until the early 20th century, when landfill connected it to Brooklyn/Long Island.
@David PTO = Paid Time Off. It‚Äôs generally what you get when you lump vacation and sick days together.

@Andrzej that one-voice saying all the lines while the originals can be heard in the background drove me CRAZY the one time I tried to see an English-language movie in Leningrad. I had to leave after 15 minutes, and the ticket lady insisted on giving me a refund, which I think was about 5 kopecks.

btw there is now a distinction in the US between subtitles and closed captioning; subtitles assume the reader can hear, and merely needs translation of a foreign language. Closed captioning includes audio descriptions like "door slam" or "wolves howling in the distance" or "eerie music".

@Bill amendation: The congressional act was named the Oloemargarine Act of 1886, and in reality applied stiff fines to manufacturers and retailers for mis-labelling it as " butter," or adulterating butter with oleo; and applied a 2¬¢ tax (per lb.?) to the substance. https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/ll/uscode/uscode1946-00202/uscode1946-002026016/uscode1946-002026016.pdf "ll substances known prior to August 2, 1886, as oleomargarine, oleo, oleomargarine oil, butterine, lardine, suine, and neutral" "Lardine," and "suine"--don't those sound tasty! @Bill 
My sister (4 yrs older, b. 1943) remembers breaking the 'capsule' of yellow dye in the bag of (unappetizingly white) margarine --and then massaging the bag to mix it--during her early years.  Mother always used margarine, but called it 'butter.'  It was years before I realized why toast at Granny and Grandpa's house was so much tastier--whole wheat bread instead of white, real butter, and Grandpa's honey!  Heavenly!

@Jay - Yup -- I think you took my tongue-in-cheek comment a bit too literally.* If I'm not going to use an absolute temperature scale, I also prefer Fahrenheit for the reason you state: it is a finer-resolution scale. 

This is the reason I also prefer metric for my woodworking. A millimeter is just about the resolution I need for most measurements and cuts, so a metric ruler is perfect. No fractions needed.

And the reason I prefer Imperial for machine work: a mil is just about the perfect resolution for most things.

@MmmmHmm - Well, that's part of what makes the puzzle, well, puzzling. 

I consider it part of the challenge, and it doesn't bother me at all. We can't make ALL puzzled incredibly simple to solve. That would be no fun at all.

@MmmmHmm That's one of the *challenges* of the game. There might be five words that fit a given category, but one of those five will be an essential part of another category, and so cannot be included in the first category. So, *before* you submit your choices for that first category, you need to figure out which of the five words actually belongs elsewhere. No need to guess at all, though that is an option. By the way, you should be posting at https://nytimes.com/spotlight/connections-companion and not here.

@MmmmHmm There is a separate comment section for connections: https://nytimes.com/spotlight/connections-companion In any case, it is absolutely not chance whether you get them or not. If you work out all 4 groups, you would know where everything belongs. There is always only 1 set of answers that works for all 4 categories. Sometimes, it looks like overlap in 2 categories, but if you look closely, you will see that one of the words doesn't fit as well as the others.

@MmmmHmm 

There are often times five possibles for a category in Connections.  You just have to find out which one belongs in another category.  I consider that situation part of the game and it's why I like it.

@Scott Yeah,   I think "keep to the plan" sounds pretty natural.   That said, I had "keep at" for the longest time .  As in "to keep at a task".    And it screwed me up.  I was unreasonably confident in that answer.   "keep to" is actually a better fit for the clue.
"[Stick with] the plan" => "KEEP TO the plan" works pretty well, I think. But if you latch on to "[Stick with] your friends" or "[Stick with] what you've got" => less so.

@Allen - That's not a rule. The answer (or derivations thereof) cannot be in the clue for it's OWN entry -- there is no rule against an answer appearing in the clue for another entry.
@Allen I thought the same thing

@Allen You are not alone in thinking that. Fun puzzle overall but that threw me for a loop! My mind went to this: Don‚Äôt repeat words in your clues that appear in the grid It can feel like a spoiler, seeing a word on the clue side of the page and later having to fill that same word into the grid. Sometimes it might be a judgment call about whether the duplicated word is really substantive. A repetition of basic articles and connector words may be permissible. https://nytimes.com/2018/07/11/crosswords/how-to-make-a-crossword-puzzle-4.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare&sgrp=c-cb
